title: What is a dominating set in graph theory? - Quora

response.answer_text: Given a graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E) a subset S⊆VS⊆V is said to be a dominating set if for every v∈Vv∈V, either v∈Sv∈S or vv is adjacent to some vertex u∈Su∈S. A few examples of dominating sets would maybe help build some intuition. Given a graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E), the entire set of vertices VV is a dominating set since every vertex belongs to the VV itself (that’s the “v∈Sv∈S" condition being satisfied for every vertex in VV). Yet, VV is clearly over the top when a graph contains edges. For example, suppose GG had at least one edge {x,y}{x,y} then V∖{x}V∖{x} or V∖{y}V∖{y} would both be dominating sets (i.e. every v≠xv≠x belongs to V∖{x}V∖{x} and xx is adjacent to yy which belongs to V∖{x}V∖{x}). Hopefully we can see from these two examples that the goal, generally speaking, is to minimize the size of the dominating set.
